intro: Aconitum moldavicum var. sinomontanum, commonly known as the Mongolian aconite, is a herbaceous perennial native to the mountainous regions of East Asia. It belongs to the Ranunculaceae family and is characterized by its tall, sparsely branched stems that can reach up to 2 meters in height. The plant produces showy blue to purple flowers in late summer, arranged in racemes at the top of the stem. Its leaves are deeply lobed and have a distinctive, almost fern-like appearance. The plant contains toxic alkaloids, making it potentially dangerous to handle or ingest.
